oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Demonbreun Cave along the Cumberland River, Nashville, Tennessee, circa 1980
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of Demonbreun’s Cave situated along the Cumberland River in downtown Nashville, Tennessee. The historic marker for the cave states that “Jacques-Timothe De Montbrun, French Canadian fur trader and later lieutenant governor of the Illinois Country, visited this area as early as 1769. On at least one occasion he took refuge in the cave 0.9 mile E. when attacked by Indians. He settled in Nashville in 1790, living there until his death in 1826.” Forms part of the Claynita Harris Slide Collection. The original is a 35 mm color transparency (2 x 2 in. slide mount)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Demonbreun family
